text:
Synopsis
The Federal Reserve is approaching the lowest comfortable level of reserves, which will likely halt Quantitative Tightening (QT) by the end of Q1 or early Q2, potentially reducing interest rate volatility and enabling increased market risk-taking.

Key Insights
- The Federal Reserve is nearing the Lowest Comfortable Level (LCL) of reserves
- QT is currently reducing the Fed's balance sheet by allowing bonds to expire
- The Fed is expected to stop QT by the end of Q1 or beginning of Q2
- Quantitative Tightening increases volatility in long-term interest rates
- Stopping QT is anticipated to reduce interest rate volatility
- Reduced volatility could encourage market participants to take on more risk and leverage
